text:
Thanks for posting this, I hadn't see it before! That was an interesting read.

It confirms my general view of Stephen Wolfram: he's a genius, an excellent writer, and he constantly oversells his work.

What he explains in this essay is that rewrite rules for hypergraphs can produce structures that share the essential properties of space-time as it is traditionally postulated as the starting point of physical theory. It is certainly not obvious that this is possible, and it is even less obvious to demonstrate that this is possible. So for anyone interested in possible computational frameworks for explaining the universe, this is very important work.

On the other hand, he clearly says that he has not (yet?) found a set of rewrite rules that is compatible with all the details of our universe as we know it. Which in turn implies that at this stage, he does not have something one could call a scientific model, something that can be used to make testable predictions.

There is a clear tradition for such work in the corner of theoretical physics looking at the foundations. String theory is famous for having lots of enthusiastic contributors in the absence of any reasonable prediction after decades of intense research.

Time will tell if anything more concrete will come out of this. Wolfram repeatedly points to the biggest obstacle on the way to a computational foundation for physics: computational irreducibility. What this means is, basically, that exploring the consequences of a computational model may require too much time for any practical use, because one would be simulating the universe on a computer necessarily much slower than the universe itself. He seems optimistic that he can escape from that problem, but it isn't very clear to me why.

text:
<@UEQ6M68H0> but the universe is a recursive function. I’d rather say a self-modifying recursive function so I’m not sure if I can call that a function since it has sideffects on itself so it isn’t pure but well, something like that - I’d say.

I love the idea and support the exploration efforts. Reminds me of my lattice structure and it’s different graphs with different rules in different dimensions, except here the rule is the one that creates while in mine the user creates. I’m not sure if bruteforcing is the right path but I assume it will give them enough data to detect some patterns and rules at evolutionary scale and discern better paths from those patterns.

text: This is great collection of "Digital Gardens", a new (to me) phenomena I've noticed of people publishing interconnected notes online. <https://twitter.com/Mappletons/status/1250532315459194880>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/Mappletons|@Mappletons>: Nerding hard on digital gardens, personal wikis, and experimental knowledge systems with <https://twitter.com/_jonesian|@_jonesian> today.

We have an epic collection going, check these out...

1. <https://twitter.com/tomcritchlow|@tomcritchlow>'s Wikifolders: <https://tomcritchlow.com/wiki/> <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EVrIC7WXgAMh96-.jpg>

elements.text: This is great collection of "Digital Gardens", a new (to me) phenomena I've noticed of people publishing interconnected notes online.

text: I just hopped on this bandwagon as well — rethinking what you can do with hypertext is really fun! I'm trying out typed links <https://twitter.com/noahtren/status/1253545273852297216?s=20>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/noahtren|@noahtren>: Happy to share some progress on a personal research blog/digital garden with "typed hyperlinks"
<https://twitter.com/noahtren/status/1245909154490875906> <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EWV8rzOXkAE5vFA.jpg>
attachments.text:
Happy to share some progress on a personal research blog/digital garden with "typed hyperlinks"
<https://twitter.com/noahtren/status/1245909154490875906> <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EWV8rzOXkAE5vFA.jpg>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/noahtren|@noahtren>: I want to experiment with "typed hyperlinks," where the link communicates something about where it's pointing to (is this a link to a blog post, wiki, video, etc?)

you could give them different colors, too. would be cool to try this with Roam Research's bidirectional links

elements.text: I just hopped on this bandwagon as well — rethinking what you can do with hypertext is really fun! I'm trying out typed links

text: (Tangent Level Rising!) Typed links is a wild idea! I've been enjoying Wikipedia's preview-on-hover feature far more than I expected I would, and I love the force-touch "peek" preview on iOS. Neat to think of other ideas for making links _partially_ bidirectional.

elements.text: (Tangent Level Rising!) Typed links is a wild idea! I've been enjoying Wikipedia's preview-on-hover feature far more than I expected I would, and I love the force-touch "peek" preview on iOS. Neat to think of other ideas for making links

text:
I heard someone describe the perfect hyperlink as a visual "portal" that you can glimpse into to see where it's leading. Instead we just get underlined text with a URL :upside_down_face:

I'm playing around with showing a Wikipedia-style abstract for posts as well as articles on hover.

text: Love it, I wish all programming was taught like this
